awd_titl_txt: Binghamton University's Graduate Conference in Algebra and Topology (BUGCAT) 2019, 2020, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
The BUGCAT conference (Binghamton University Graduate Conference in Algebra and Topology) is a yearly conference at Binghamton University, that has been running since 2008. It is aimed primarily at the graduate students and recent PhDs in Algebra, Topology, and related areas of mathematics. The current grant will support the conference for the next three years, starting with BUGCAT 2019 which will be held from November 2-3, 2019. The conference website is https://www2.math.binghamton.edu/p/bugcat/start.

Conference participation is an irreplaceable component in the development of young mathematicians. It is especially helpful if a conference is run at the level appropriate for graduates students so that they can both understand the various ideas and trends and present their own research. This is especially important for the members of underrepresented  groups: they are often more prone to being unduly intimidated by high-level research conferences. The BUGCAT conference is run for the graduate students, by the graduate students, with a diverse group of organizers. It strives to provide an inclusive environment for young researchers in Algebra, Topology, and related fields. These are some of the traditional areas of strength at Binghamton University, with a large number of local graduate student participants and organizers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This conference grant was initially awarded for 2019, 2020, and 2021 to Binghamton University Graduate Conference in Algebra and Topology (BUGCAT). This is a long-running  yearly conference, aimed at graduate students in two areas of pure mathematics, traditionally well represented at Binghamton University. 

    Because of the COVID pandemic restrictions, the 2020 and 2021 events were held online; the funding was used for 2022 and 2023 conferences instead. We were able not just to hold the conference, but  to grow it, to more than 100 registered participants. It also grew in mathematical breadth, to include Combinatorics. Since 2021 the event is called the Binghamton University Graduate Combinatorics, Algebra, and Topology Conference (BUGCAT Conference).

    A key aspect of the conference is that it is organized primarily by a rolling group of graduate students in the Binghamton University Department of Mathematics and Statistics, with a faculty P.I.'s help and oversight. So one important outcome of this project is helping our graduate students understand first-hand what is involved in running a large conference. This experience has been helping them both learn how to do it and to appreciate better the organizers' role in any conferences that they themselves attend.

     We are continuing and expanding the wonderful tradition of a graduate-student-run conference for graduate students, with a friendly and inclusive atmosphere to help all participants' mathematical development.
